com.pb.sawdust.tabledata.read

Class MultiTextTableReader<S,R extends TextFileTableReader<S>>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.pb.sawdust.tabledata.read.MultiTextTableReader<S,R>

  • public class MultiTextTableReader<S,R extends TextFileTableReader<S>>
extends java.lang.Object
    The MultiTextTableReader class provides a TextFileTableReader implementation wherein multiple data tables can be read from a single file. It essentially runs multiple TextFileTableReader instances through the same file. The advantage of this class, which is especially important if the input file is large, is that it only reads the file once. If the readers contained by this class are supposed to act on distinct parts of the file (i.e. some lines belong to one table, the others to another), then the readers should have line filters set to ignore the non-relevant parts of the file.

    When reading in data tables from a file, this class allocates the processing of file lines to each reader in parallel. Because of this, one reader's line processing may be quicker than anothers, allowing it to "get ahead" of the other(s), which could cause some memory issues. In the worst case scenario, the entire file might be held in memory (the "fast" reader has finished processing and the "slow" reader is still working on the first line). To offer some control over this, this class allows the specification of a maximum file line queue size - that is, the maximum number of file lines that can be held in memory at any one time.

    There are a couple of restrictions on the readers contained by an instance of this class. Specifically, each reader must be set up to read in the same file, and each reader must produce a data table with a different name. Since each reader must read the same file, this implies that one cannot allow more than one reader to use a default data table name (which is based one the file name).

    • Constructor Detail

      • MultiTextTableReader

        public MultiTextTableReader(R[] readers,
                    int parallelIteratorQueueSize)
        Constructor specifying the readers and the maximum number of file lines that can be held in memory.
        Parameters:
        readers - The readers which will process the input file(s).
        parallelIteratorQueueSize - The maximum number of file lines that can be held in memory at any one time.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the number of readers is less than two
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if any two readers create tables with the same name, or if the readers do not all read the same file.

      • MultiTextTableReader

        public MultiTextTableReader(R[] readers)
        Constructor specifying the readers. The maximum number of file lines allowed in memory at any one time is set to 50,000.
        Parameters:
        readers - The readers which will process the input file(s).
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the number of readers is less than two
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if any two readers create tables with the same name, or if the readers do not all read the same file.

    • Method Detail

      • getReader

        public TextFileTableReader<S> getReader(java.lang.String tableName)
        Get the reader contained by this instance that will produce a data table with a specified name.
        Parameters:
        tableName - The table name in question.
        Returns:
        the reader that creates a data table named tableName.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if no reader in this instance creates a data table named tableName.

      • getReaders

        public java.util.Collection<? extends TextFileTableReader<S>> getReaders()
        Get a collection of the readers contained by this instance. The returned readers will be wrapped in such a way that they are not modifiable (they can be used to read data, but their internal state cannot be changed).
        Returns:
        the readers contained by this instance.
